awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Collaborative Research: Leveraging Randomization and Human Behavior for Efficient Large-Scale Distributed Spectrum Access
awd_abstract_narration:
An explosion of low-cost wireless devices promises new applications and services in diverse domains, including health, transportation, energy, manufacturing, and entertainment. This project focuses on developing energy and spectrum-efficient, distributed multi-access strategies for dynamic and large-scale wireless networks under the stringent energy and delay requirements that are expected in emerging applications. This work will enable the development of a multitude of technologies that can improve the life of society-at-large. For example, this work can support the next generation of communication technologies for large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) applications and autonomous vehicle applications. Moreover, education is a core component of this project. New theories and algorithms developed in this project are integrated into the graduate-level courses at the three universities. Undergraduate and graduate students are involved in the project through the undergrad capstone and masters graduation projects at the Ohio State University.

This project explores the fundamental energy and spectrum-efficiency tradeoff of distributed spectrum access methods, and develops adaptive and correlated strategies that embrace and control randomness with efficiency guarantees for dynamic users with delay-sensitive traffic. In addition, the design incorporates humans into the loop by observing how humans react in simple multi-access games, providing simple human behavior models and simple human-perceived quality metrics, and by designing methods that can adapt to unexpected events or actions. A combined analysis and implementation approach of this project exploits high-dimensionality in the system while also overcoming difficulties for large-scale implementation and testing. In particular, the project develops mean-field techniques and analyses for large-scale spectrum access. Novel real-world experimentation strategies developed in this project emulate large-scale system operation in a small testbed by utilizing the simplification due to our randomized solutions and the integration of the aforementioned mean-field methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project is to design energy and spectrum-efficient strategies for scalable spectrum access of dynamic and large-scale user populations under low-energy and stringent delay requirements. This goal is motivated by the rapid growth of low-cost wireless devices that promise new services in diverse domains, including health, transportation, energy, and entertainment. The capabilities and service requirements of these devices can vary greatly between very energy-limited and low-rate devices such as RFID tags, to highly powerful and throughput-hungry smart devices. Applications within the domain of Internet-of-Things (IoT) present scenarios where many mobile devices have small bundles of packets to transmit under strict delay constraints. As such this project tackles the pressing need for the design of efficient communication mechanisms for the wide-band and time-varying spectrum that such distributed users can share under the next generation wireless technologies. 

 

On the intellectual merit front, the project has explored the fundamental energy-efficiency and spectrum-utilization tradeoff of adaptive and randomized multi-access methods that embrace and control the dynamics of distributed users and sources for provably efficient  spectrum access. To that end, the project has addressed both of the two fundamentally different scenarios of dynamic users and of dynamic sources. The former scenario of dynamic users concerns efficient spectrum access for distributed users with small amount of information to be transmitted over the shared spectrum. On this front, the project has led to the development of both `congestion-based? and `age-based? spectrum access protocols, both of which posses asymptotic throughput maximization guarantees, but neither of which is superior  to the other under non-asymptotic conditions. With their low-overhead and de-centralized nature, these protocols have the potential of benefiting future multi-user spectrum access technologies. In contrast, the latter scenario of dynamic sources concerns efficient spectrum access for keeping evolving or refreshing states of distributed  sources fresh at a remote location. Such a scenario is relevant to IoT applications as well as content distribution networks, whereby content of different sources is refreshed as new updates are generated. On this front, the project has inspired various concerted efforts for `fresh? caching for dynamic content as well as `remote tracking? for evolving states of distributed sources. These efforts have helped develop a new framework of spectrum access for fresh caching and for distributed remote tracking. 

 

On the broader impact front, the design of energy-efficient and scalable spectrum access methods for delay-sensitive and energy-limited devices is essential to enabling the development of a multitude of technologies that can improve the life of society at large. To name a few, these include next generation communication technologies that aim to incorporate large-scale IoT applications that will open new markets for providing new services to the public (including health, manufacturing, entertainment), and safe and efficient transportation strategies in view of the ongoing autonomous vehicle revolution. Education and training of the next generation of engineers and academicians is a core component of this project. The project has integrated research and education by including new theories and algorithms developed in this project into the graduate-level courses at the participating institutions. Accordingly, the project has contributed to the training and education of the next generation of communication engineers that is essential to the success of the industry.
